When a capacitor of capacitance C is charged using a battery of voltage V and a switch, the battery expends an amount of energy QV while the energy stored in the capacitor (after charging) is QV/2 where Q represents the amount of charge transferred when the capacitor voltage is V. Note that with a potential difference V, a capacitor C will store charge Q, but the energy stored is not Q × V. Why not? Because, as the capacitor charges, both Q and V increase, so we have not moved all the charge with a potential difference of V across the capacitor (fighting against the growing fringe field to transfer energy from the battery), which the battery did.  Where is the missing energy? (QV)/2 from the battery?    Electrostatics and circuits belong to one science not two. To learn the operation of circuits it is instructive to understand Current, the conduction process and Voltage at the fundamental level as in the following two videos: i. https://youtu.be/REsWdd76qxc and  ii. https://youtu.be/8BQM_xw2Rfo   It is not possible in this post to discuss in more detail the energy expended when a capacitor is charged. The last frame References in video #1  lists textbook 4 which discusses these topics in more detail using a unified approach and provides an intuitive understanding of how charging a capacitor with a ramp voltage is more energy efficient than by applying a step voltage.

.Based just purely off what I found online, it looks like the equation for electric potential energy is different when dealing with a particle than when dealing with dialectric stuff like capacitors, because capacitors and such have to deal with the resistance from the bunch of electrons they're moving resisting eachother. So Ue=vq when dealing with like a particle in an electric field, but Ue=1/2vq when dealing with stuff like capacitors.
A Farad has unit of c/v  (coulomb per volt) if you multiply (c/v)*v^2 it will result in c*v. A volt is J/c (Joule per coulomb), so (J/c)*c = J

You can derive the formula using integration. The idea behind the integration is that the work applied to move dq (very small amount) of charge from one plate to another depends on how much charge is already on the other plate. The summation of work (where the integration comes in) from one side to another is equal to the potential energy of the system before any charge is moved over. Once the integral is solved you end up with U = Q^2/2C after integrating with respect to Q.
Q=CV V=Q/C..........(1)  U=1/2.QV² but V=Q/C  Therefore U=1/2.Q.(Q/C)  U=1/2.Q²/C

Basically, we know that E = V*Q. Now the voltage of the capacitor will keep decreasing from say V to 0 by the time it discharges. So the average Voltage would be V/2. So, we know that C = Q/V, so Q = C*V. Now substituting this into E = V*Q, you get E = CV^2 * 1/2.
